div.l: Alein wax weri in the morninge
For he had swonken al the long niȝt
And seid fare wel Malkyn swete wiȝt
The day is come I may no lenger abide
But euermore where so I go or ride
I is thin ougne clerk so haue I sele
Now dere lemman quod she go fare wel
But or thou go a thing I wol the telle
Whan thou wendest homward bi the melle
Riȝt at the entre of the dore behinde
Thou shalt a cake of a busshel finde
That was ymaked of thin ougne mele
Wich that I helpe my self for to stele
And gode lemman̄ god the saue and kepe
And with that word almost she began to wepe
Alein vprist and thouȝt or that it dawe
I wol go crepe in be my felawe
And fonde the cradel with his hond anon̄
Be god quod he al wrang I had misgon
Myn hed is toty of my swink to niȝt
That makes me that I go nat ariȝt
I wat wel bi the cradell I haue misganmisganmisga
Hiere liest the Millere and his wif alswa
And forth he goth a twenti deuel way
Vnto the bedde there as the Millere lay
He went haue cropen̄ be his felawe Iohn
And bi the Millere in he crepe anon̄
And cauȝt him bi the necke and softe he spak
He seide thou Iohn thou swines hed awak
For cristes saule and hiere a noble game
For bi that lord that callid is Seint Iame
As I haue thries in this short niȝt
Swifed the Millers douȝter bolt vpright
Whil thou hast as a coward ben agast
Ye false harlot quod the Millere hast
A fals traitour fals clerk quod he
Thou shalt be ded be goddes dignite
Who durst be so bold to disparage
My douȝter that is com of so high linage
And bi the throte bolle he cauȝt Aleyn̄
And he hent hem despitousli agein
And on the nose he smot him with his fist
